Most employees are covered by Social Security. There are four different contribution schedules for Social Security covered members. In 2011, 63% of members paid 8%. Members are automatically enrolled in tier 1, but may elect tier 2 instead. In 2011, 150,826 participants belonged to tier 1, compared with only 7,204 participants in tier 2. Plan identifies 55 as the normal retirement age; however, it pays the maximum benefit at age 63. Purchasing Power Protection Allowance (PPPA) supplements benefits so that they are at least 75 percent of their original purchasing power adjusted for inflation. Our analysis assumes that all employees are covered by Social Security.

Most employees are covered by Social Security. There are four different contribution schedules for Social Security covered members. In 2011, 63% of members paid 8%. Members are automatically enrolled in tier 1, but may elect tier 2 instead. In 2011, 150,826 participants belonged to tier 1, compared with only 7,204 participants in tier 2. Plan identifies 62 as the normal retirement age; however, it pays the maximum benefit at age 67. FAS is capped at the Social Security taxable maximum if covered by Social Security or 120% of the taxable maximum if not covered. Purchasing Power Protection Allowance (PPPA) supplements benefits so that they are at least 75 percent of their original purchasing power adjusted for inflation. Our analysis assumes that all employees are covered by Social Security.

The Article 7 date is the date at which employees were eligible to retire as of September 30, 2009. It created tiers A, B, AB, B1, and B2.  The Rhode Island Retirement Security Act of 2011 (RIRSA) created a hybrid plan effective July 1, 2012. For those eligible to retire on June 30, 2012, RIRSA does not change their retirement eligibility age.  For everyone else, the retirement eligibility age is Social Security's normal retirement age; however, it is adjusted downward toward an earlier retirement date based on years of service before July 1, 2012. Also, starting on July 1, 2012 everyone has their 8.75% contribution rate split with 3.75% to the DB plan and 5% to the DC plan. In addition, all YOS after June 30, 2012 have a multiplier of 1%.

Texas County and District Retirement System

Local government chooses plan parameters. The mandatory employee contribution may be set between 4% and 7% of pay, matching rate may be set between 100% and 250% of employee contributions, and vesting may be set at 5, 8 , or 10 years. Employees may qualify for benefits if age plus YOS = 75 or 80, if they are age 60 and vested, if they have completed 20 years of service regardless of age, or if they have completed 30 years of service regardless of age.
